segments.text: And he was telling that the university administration thinks that McDonald either lies to them or is incompetent to give them a straight answer about how much something is going to cost.
So continue.
So in the early days of the 300-inch project, where Pete Flan was president and Harlan was pushing it very hard, the...
In my opinion, and I've never had Pete Flawn say this one way or another, or Jerry Falcon say it, who had become Flawn's vice president for research and then later executive vice president provost.
In my opinion, they made us jump through so many hoops.
They wanted outside reviews on a number of occasions.
were extraordinarily cautious in believing the information we sent up to them.
And then in my opinion, that delayed the project so long that the oil crunch in Texas happened and killed it.
And that, I've said to other people that,
Without Harlan Smith, there would never, ever have been a 300-inch project.
With Harlan Smith, it was impossible to accomplish a 300-inch telescope project because the relations between him and the administration were such that it took too damn long to develop it.
We almost had the same problem with the SST.
We began involvement in the SST in 1985.
We started talking with Penn State.
In 1987, we entered into an agreement with them.
But as late as 1992, the UT administration, with a new president, same vice president for research, were having difficulty believing anything we told them.
And we almost lost the SST, even after Harlan, because of that history that had been built up.

they i think quite literally they simply did not trust him they respected his his incredible entrepreneurial ability and they they respected his ability to communicate with the public they respected his ability to raise money and to convince people of the rightness of the programs he was pursuing but i literally believe they did not trust him uh

After my wife and I lived most of the last 10 years up in New England, and frankly, what anybody knows about the University of Texas, not just from Stardate, but from McDonald Observatory, that's what the University of Texas is known for in that part of the country and in the Midwest, too, where all my ancestors are.
Do you think the administration at UT appreciates that?
Well, the administration at UT just changed.
We're now on about the fifth president since I've been there.
They come and they go.

The new president, I can't say if he does or not, but I can tell you this, that I'm optimistic because at the first Board of Visitors meeting that we had in February, at which the new president took over in January, Robert Berdahl, who came from the University of Illinois,
He stood up in front of it and he said, long before I ever knew that I would show up here at the University of Texas as president, I had enjoyed listening on the radio in Illinois to Stardate.
And he said, I'm really appreciative of what the observatory does in that regard.
So he obviously had started out on the right foot.
The previous president,
Bill Cunningham was very strongly supportive of us all during his term.
And without him, the spectroscopic survey telescope would have died.
The president before that was Pete Flan.
And one of the first things he said, I can remember driving across town and hearing it on my radio in my car.
He was giving a halftime talk at a football game.
They were interviewing him at halftime, not a talk.
He was being interviewed.
And they asked that question, what are the preeminent programs at UT Austin now that you've just taken over as president?
And the first one out of his mouth was the McDonald Observatory and the Department of Astronomy program is preeminent as a jewel in our crown, or some words to that effect.
So I think the presidents have had an appreciation for the excellence of the program in astronomy at Texas.
I think as money gets tighter and tighter, they are...
There's a little bit of the climate, what have you done for us lately type of attitude, which they have to take.
They have to decide what's strong today, not what was strong 10 or 20 years ago.
What's strong today?
And how is that going to help this university?
And so we have to continually read.
50 years ago, Harvard was the preeminent astronomy department.
But them days is gone forever.
